title: 106_hr2796
content: Section 301(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Super Majority Requirement is also amended. Section 3 focuses on removing Social Security from budget pronouncements. The Office of Management and Budget, Congressional Budget Office, and other federal agencies must exclude Social Security program outlays and receipts from budget totals. Separate budget documents for Social Security are required. The outlays and receipts of the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance program under title II of the Social Security Act must be submitted in separate budget documents. Establishment of Debt Reduction Lockbox. The Debt Reduction Lockbox is established within the Treasury to retire publicly held debt obligations of the United States Government. Appropriations for the lockbox are specified for fiscal years 2000 to 2006, ranging from $7 billion to $64.5 billion annually. The Debt Reduction Lockbox is established to retire publicly held debt obligations of the United States Government. Appropriations for fiscal years 2006 to 2009 are $64.5 billion, $73 billion, $78.5 billion, and $89 billion respectively. The Secretary of the Treasury uses funds to purchase or redeem debt obligations. Adjustments are made based on budget surplus changes before the President's budget submission for fiscal years 2001 to 2004. The Office of Management and Budget determines adjustments to the Deficit Reduction Lockbox based on projected budget surplus calculations at the end of each fiscal year. The Director calculates changes in surplus projections using updated economic and technical assumptions, comparing them to the Congressional Budget Office's report. The Debt Reduction Lockbox amounts are restricted from appropriation, expenditure, or transfer, and are exempt from budget reduction orders. The Debt Reduction Lockbox is listed among government trust funds and requires the President to report annually on its status, including amounts in and Federal debt redeemed. The Lockbox amounts are protected from appropriation, expenditure, or transfer, and are exempt from budget reduction orders. The Debt Reduction Lockbox is safeguarded from budget reductions and appropriations. Any budget resolution or legislation must meet the minimum amount set forth in title 31, United States Code. The Debt Reduction Lockbox is protected from budget reductions and appropriations. Any bill, resolution, amendment, motion, or conference report must meet a minimum surplus amount specified in the most recent budget resolution to be enacted. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include the amount of the Debt Reduction Lockbox and a super majority requirement for certain sections. SEC. 6. DEBT REDUCTION DIVIDEND FOR SOCIAL SECURITY. The amendment to the Social Security Act introduces a debt reduction dividend to be determined annually by the Secretary of the Treasury. The dividend is the excess of $229 billion over the previous year's net interest expenditures. Funds equal to 100% of this dividend are reserved for social security and medicare reform, with 75% allocated to social security and 25% to medicare. The amendment introduces a debt reduction dividend determined annually by the Secretary of the Treasury. 100% of the dividend is reserved for social security and medicare reform, with 75% for social security and 25% for medicare. Funds transferred to the Trust Funds for reform legislation are exempt from the pay-as-you-go requirement and sequestration under the Balanced Budget Act. The amendment introduces a debt reduction dividend for social security and medicare reform. Medicare reform legislation extends the solvency of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund for 20 years.
